snippet: Dozens of players have joined demonstrations over the university’s handling of racial tensions on campus, vowing to skip team activities until the president resigns or is removed.
abstract: Black football players at University of Missouri in Columbia have refused to play until university president Timothy M Wolfe, who has been criticized for slow response to racist incidents on campus, resigns; strike points to growing push among black college students at predominantly white institutions to demand strong action from administrators in face of racism; boycott could cost school $1 million if Saturday game does not proceed as scheduled.

byline.original: By MARC TRACY and ASHLEY SOUTHALL
byline.contributor: Marc Tracy reported from Columbia, and Ashley Southall from New York. Jack Healy and Alan Blinder contributed reporting from New York, and Austin Huguelet from Columbia.

lead_paragraph: Dozens of players have joined demonstrations over the university’s handling of racial tensions on campus, vowing to skip team activities until the president resigns or is removed.

headline.main: Black Football Players Lend Heft to Protests at Missouri
headline.print_headline: No Justice, No Football on a Missouri Campus
